content.webTitle: Lib Dem minister: any post-election coalition talks should be confidential

fields.headline: Lib Dem minister: any post-election coalition talks should be confidential
fields.bodyText: The minister for schools, David Laws, has argued that any coalition talks after the general election should be held in secret, without civil servants in attendance. In a keynote speech at thinktank the Institute for Government on Monday, the Liberal Democrat MP for Yeovil said he thought that the way the coalition was formed in May 2010, without the then head of the civil service, Gus O’Donnell, in attendance, allowed politicians to “cut to the chase more quickly and have slightly more candid, productive arguments”. He said that coalition talks are more effective when politicians don’t “feel they’re being minuted and recorded by civil servants than when they feel that everything is being done in a more public way”. Laws argued that it can be difficult for the civil service to maintain complete independence when it is drawn in to advising different political parties. He continued: “I think it was William Hague in May 2010 who joked, when we locked Gus O’Donnell out of the door … that at least now he wouldn’t need to worry about freedom of information requests coming in about what we were discussing and, sure enough, on the very last day of the coalition talks … the civil service received the first freedom of information request from some industrious journalist asking for the minutes from all our coalition talks. We were able to say quite honestly that there were no government minutes.” In a speech that responded to a report from the Institute of Government on effective governance, Laws predicted that possible coalition negotiations after the upcoming general election would take about two days more than the five days it took to form the current government. The uncertain economic situation put pressure on the Liberal Democrats to reach a quick coalition deal with the Conservative party in 2010, argued Laws, and parties involved in coalition deals in May will expect much more detailed coalition agreements. Laws also predicted that there would be more consultation with MPs in any future coalition agreement: “Party leaders negotiated on behalf of their entire parties and then told the parties afterwards more or less what had been done. There will be a higher expectation of engagement next time around.” Responding to criticism over the rising cost of special advisers, Laws argued that they provide ministers with policy advice that has a “necessary political dimension”, something that it is not easy for civil servants to provide. Laws dedicated considerable time to defending the model of coalition government, saying that those who said coalitions produced chaos had been proved “utterly wrong”. “I would argue that this coalition government has been as effective as any single-party government in my lifetime and considerably more effective than most of the single-party governments in my lifetime,” he said.
